questions.text: A 42-year-old man comes to the physician because he is concerned that he is balding. Over the past few months, he has noticed patchy areas of hair loss on his head. He also mentions that he has felt depressed since the death of his wife last year and has unintentionally lost about 18 kg (40 lb). He is constantly fatigued. He has little appetite because he feels food does not taste the same way anymore. He also has occasional episodes of watery diarrhea. He drinks 5–6 cans of beer daily. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows dry, scaly skin on both feet. There is patchy alopecia of the scalp, axillae, chest, and mons pubis. Which of the following is most likely to improve this patient's alopecia?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Finasteride is used to treat androgenetic alopecia. While the condition is the most common cause of alopecia in men and should always be considered, the hair typically recedes in an M-shaped pattern along the hairline. Patchy, generalized hair loss and gastrointestinal symptoms cannot be explained by androgenetic alopecia.
Image Description:

Non-scarring hair loss can be seen at the temporal scalp.

This is the characteristic pattern of male pattern hair loss.

B) INCORRECT:

Griseofulvin is a medication used to treat fungal infections, including conditions like tinea capitis. While tinea capitis impairs hair growth and can cause alopecia, it almost exclusively affects the scalp and manifests with pruritic, round scaly plaques that are not present in this patient.
Image Description:

Scalp of a child

There is a round, almost hairless plaque with coarse scaling.

The patient was diagnosed with superficial tinea capitis caused by dermatophytes.

C) CORRECT:

This patient presents with symptoms of zinc deficiency (diarrhea, dermatitis, abnormal taste, alopecia), which is most likely caused by insufficient dietary intake and chronic heavy alcohol use. Oral zinc supplementation is the most effective treatment for managing symptoms of deficiency as well as restoring normal hair growth.

D) INCORRECT:

Levothyroxine administration is indicated in individuals with hypothyroidism. Although hypothyroidism can also cause hair loss and fatigue, it typically leads to weight gain and constipation and is therefore unlikely to be the cause of this patient's symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Triamcinolone is a corticosteroid that is used to treat alopecia areata, a condition that causes patchy hair loss and that can affect any part of the body. Since the disease typically manifests with an acute onset in individuals < 30 years of age and is not associated with skin lesions or gastrointestinal complaints, this diagnosis is unlikely.
Image Description:

There are well-demarcated, patchy areas of hair loss without scarring of the scalp.

F) INCORRECT:

Habit reversal training is used for the treatment of trichotillomania, a disorder characterized by the compulsion to pull out one's hair, which leads to nonscarring, patchy hair loss. Although trichotillomania is associated with other psychiatric conditions that may be present in this patient (e.g., major depressive disorder) and could have been triggered by his wife's death, he shows no uncontrollable urge to pull his hair.
Image Description:

There are patches of hair of varying length. The hair density is normal (including new hair growth).
questions.hint: Patients with this diagnosis may also have delayed wound healing and hypogonadism.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of hair loss and a rash on her face. She has also noticed that food has recently tasted bland to her. Her medical history is remarkable for Crohn disease, for which she had to undergo segmental small bowel resection several times because of intestinal obstruction and fistula formation. She was previously started on infliximab, which she stopped taking 9 months ago. Examination shows several bullous, erythematous perioral plaques. There are two well-circumscribed circular patches of hair loss on her scalp. A deficiency of which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Retinoic acid (vitamin A) deficiency can manifest with dry, scaly skin (xerosis cutis). However, this patient lacks other typical features of vitamin A deficiency, such as night blindness, xerophthalmia, and corneal degeneration. Moreover, perioral plaques, altered sense of taste, and alopecia are not consistent with this deficiency.

B) INCORRECT:

Ascorbic acid (vitamin C) deficiency (also known as scurvy) can manifest with dermatitis. However, this patient lacks typical features of vitamin C deficiency, such as gingivitis, mucosal bleeding, curly body hair, arthralgia, and follicular hyperkeratosis. Finally, altered sense of taste and alopecia are not commonly seen in scurvy.

C) INCORRECT:

Niacin deficiency (also known as pellagra) can manifest with dermatitis. However, dermatitis associated with pellagra typically manifests as a symmetrical rash with hyperpigmented lesions on sun-exposed areas. This patient lacks additional features of niacin deficiency, such as glossitis, dementia, and diarrhea. Finally, altered sense of taste and alopecia are not consistent with pellagra.
Image Description:

Pellagra can be deadly if left untreated (due to the formerly high mortality rate, “death” is sometimes still listed as the fourth “D” of pellagra). Populations with a diet low in niacin-rich foods (e.g., corn-based diets without proper preparation) are at higher risk.

D) INCORRECT:

Cobalamin (Vitamin B12) deficiency can be seen in patients with inflammation of the terminal ileum (e.g., as seen in Crohn disease), where cobalamin is absorbed. This deficiency typically manifests with dry skin and altered taste sensation. However, other features of cobalamin deficiency, such as fatigue, peripheral neuropathy, symmetric paresthesias, numbness, and gait abnormalities, are absent in this patient. Moreover, cobalamin deficiency does not explain this patient's erythematous perioral plaques.

E) INCORRECT:

Selenium deficiency is a very rare nutritional deficiency that occurs most often in populations dependent on selenium-depleted soil for agriculture. Known manifestations of selenium deficiency include hypothyroidism (as thyroid hormone production is dependent on selenium) and myocardial necrosis leading to heart failure (for reasons that remain unclear). This patient's symptoms are not consistent with selenium deficiency.

F) INCORRECT:

Iron deficiency may also cause hair loss, which is seen in this patient. Furthermore, because iron is normally absorbed in the duodenum, Crohn disease is a risk factor for this type of deficiency. Iron deficiency most commonly manifests with easy fatigability, shortness of breath, conjunctival pallor, and weakness (all attributable to iron deficiency anemia), as well as koilonychia and pica. This patient lacks these other cardinal findings. Moreover, iron deficiency would not explain this patient's dysgeusia and dermatitis.

G) CORRECT:

Zinc deficiency can lead to a constellation of clinical features including immune dysfunction, impaired wound healing, hypogonadism, diarrhea, dermatitis, alopecia, abnormal sense of taste (dysgeusia), and an abnormal sense of smell (dysosmia). Etiologies include poor dietary intake, impaired absorption (e.g., due to Crohn disease), congenital conditions (e.g., acrodermatitis enteropathica), and liver or renal disease. Crohn disease and numerous small bowel resections have most likely substantially impaired this patient's ability to absorb zinc, thereby predisposing her to zinc deficiency.

Zinc is a mineral that is vital for the function of numerous enzymes and is essential for the synthesis of zinc-finger transcription factors.
questions.hint: A congenital cause of the same deficiency is Acrodermatitis enteropathica, which can manifest with depressed immunity, resulting in frequent infections and, in males, decreased spermatogenesis.

questions.text: A previously healthy 20-year-old woman comes to the physician because of recurrent abdominal cramps, bloating, and diarrhea for the past 4 months. She describes her stools as greasy, foul-smelling, and difficult to flush. During this time she has had a 6-kg (13.2-lb) weight loss. She has no personal or family history of serious illness. Physical examination shows pallor and cheilitis. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 11 g/dL. Serum concentrations of electrolytes, urea nitrogen, and creatinine are within the reference range. Test of the stool for occult blood is negative and stool microscopy reveals no pathogens and no leukocytes. Analysis of a 24-hour stool sample shows 12 g (N < 7) of fat. The patient is asked to consume 25 g of d-xylose. Five hours later, its concentration is measured in urine at 2 g (N = > 4 g/5 h). The test is repeated after a two-week course of rifaximin, but the urinary concentration of d-xylose remains the same. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Bacterial overgrowth in the small intestine

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Autoimmune-mediated inflammation of the colon is the underlying mechanism of ulcerative colitis (UC), which can manifest with recurrent abdominal pain, diarrhea, anemia, and weight loss. UC most frequently occurs in individuals 15–35 years of age. However, because the small intestine is not usually affected in UC, the absorption of nutrients here remains unchanged. Therefore, steatorrhea would be absent and urine d-xylose concentration would be normal. Moreover, patients with UC typically present with bloody stools.

B) INCORRECT:

Lactose intolerance is a very common condition caused by an inability to digest lactose. While it also causes abdominal pain, bloating, and diarrhea, lactose intolerance is not associated with steatorrhea, anemia, cheilitis, or weight loss. Lactose intolerance does not affect the integrity or absorptive capacity of the small intestinal mucosa, meaning urine d-xylose levels would be normal.

C) INCORRECT:

Exocrine pancreatic insufficiency can manifest with abdominal cramps, steatorrhea, and weight loss due to lipase deficiency. However, pancreatic insufficiency does not alter the integrity or absorptive capacity of the small intestinal mucosa, meaning that urine d-xylose levels would be normal. Moreover, causes of exocrine pancreatic insufficiency like cystic fibrosis and chronic pancreatitis do not typically manifest in this age group.

D) INCORRECT:

Tropheryma whipplei is the causative agent of Whipple disease (WD), a rare multisystem infection. Gastrointestinal symptoms of WD include abdominal cramps, diarrhea, and steatorrhea. As WD affects the absorptive capacity of the small intestine, the d-xylose test would also be positive. However, WD primarily affects men > 40 years of age, and most patients have a history of migratory arthralgias affecting large joints, making another more common condition more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (SIBO) can manifest with diarrhea, steatorrhea, and weight loss. Bacterial proliferation impairs the absorptive capacity of the small intestine, leading to a positive d-xylose test. However, the administration of rifaximin would resolve SIBO, resulting in improved small intestinal absorptive capacity and normal urinary d-xylose levels. Additionally, this patient does not have any predisposing factors for SIBO such as blind loop syndrome, intestinal strictures (e.g., postoperative, tuberculosis, Crohn disease), or conditions that decrease intestinal motility (e.g., chronic diabetes mellitus, scleroderma).

F) CORRECT:

Hypersensitivity to gliadin is the underlying cause of celiac disease, which manifests with steatorrhea, weight loss, and features of iron deficiency (pallor and cheilitis). Malabsorption, supported by a positive d-xylose test (carbohydrate malabsorption), high fecal fat content (fat malabsorption), and low hemoglobin (micronutrient malabsorption), is typical of celiac disease. A d-xylose test that remains positive after a course of antibiotics indicates a noninfectious cause of malabsorption.

The gold standard for diagnosing celiac disease is the measurement of serum IgA anti‑tissue transglutaminase antibodies (tTG) and total IgA. If total IgA is normal and IgA tTG is high, an endoscopy-guided intestinal biopsy should be obtained (while the patient is still on a diet that contains gluten) to confirm the diagnosis.
questions.hint: D-xylose is a monosaccharide that is directly absorbed by the small intestinal mucosa without enzymatic breakdown and is primarily excreted via urine. After consumption of d-xylose, urinary levels of this monosaccharide typically increase. Loss of absorptive capacity of the small intestinal mucosa leads to a low urinary d-xylose concentration, known as a positive d-xylose test.

questions.text: Eight weeks after starting a new weight-loss medication, a 43-year-old woman with obesity comes to the physician because of greasy diarrhea, excessive belching, and flatulence. She also complains of progressively worsening night-time vision. She has had no fever, chills, or vomiting. Physical examination shows dry, scaly skin on her extremities and face. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of action of the drug she is taking?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Amphetamines stimulate the release of monoamine neurotransmitters and can be used to induce weight loss. The most common adverse effects of amphetamines include tachycardia, hypertension, and appetite suppression. Steatorrhea and symptoms of fat-soluble vitamin malabsorption are not consistent with amphetamine use.

B) INCORRECT:

SSRIs can be prescribed to reduce weight in patients with binge eating disorder, especially in those with concomitant depression. Although adverse effects of SSRIs include diarrhea, steatorrhea and other symptoms of fat malabsorption are not common. More typical side effects of SSRIs such as somnolence/insomnia, dizziness, headaches, and nausea would be expected instead. This patient has no history of binge eating disorder or depression, which makes this medication unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Phentermine, which stimulates norepinephrine release, can be used as a weight-loss agent. However, the most common adverse effects include cardiovascular symptoms (e.g., tachycardia, hypertension, and palpitations) and constipation, rather than diarrhea and symptoms associated with fat malabsorption, which is seen here.

D) CORRECT:

Lipase inhibitors such as orlistat inactivate gastric and pancreatic lipase enzymes within the intestine, preventing the complete hydrolyzation of dietary fats into monoglycerides and fatty acids. This decreases the amount of fat absorbed in the gastrointestinal tract and increases fecal fat excretion. Adverse effects of orlistat, therefore, include symptoms of fat malabsorption, such as steatorrhea, abdominal cramps, and bloating. It may also cause fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies (in this case, vitamin A deficiency).

E) INCORRECT:

GLP1 agonists facilitate insulin secretion in response to food. They can be used to achieve weight loss, especially in patients with pre-existing T2DM and cardiovascular disease, which this patient does not have. Although common adverse effects of this class of medications include GI disturbances, steatorrhea and other symptoms of fat malabsorption would not be expected.
questions.hint: This patient's greasy diarrhea and symptoms of vitamin A deficiency (poor night vision, xeroderma) are characteristic adverse effects related to orlistat, a weight-loss medication.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with alcohol use disorder is brought to the physician by his sister for frequent falls and an unsteady gait over the past 2 months. He has not seen a physician in 10 years. He appears emaciated and inattentive. He is oriented to person only. Physical examination shows a wide-based gait with slow, short steps. Eye examination shows lateral gaze paralysis and horizontal nystagmus. One month later, he dies. Which of the following is the most likely finding on autopsy?

choices.text: Small vessel hemorrhage in mammillary bodies
Atrophy of the caudate and putamen

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Small vessel hemorrhage and necrosis in the mammillary bodies of the hypothalamus can be found in patients with Wernicke encephalopathy, a sequela of severe thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency. Thiamine deficiency causes neuronal injury and impaired axonal conduction, which leads to a classic triad of confusion/memory loss, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia. Alcohol use disorder, as seen in this patient, decreases intake, absorption, and hepatic storage of thiamine, and is the most important risk factor associated with Wernicke encephalopathy.
Image Description:

Cranial MRI (T2-weighted; axial view)

Bilateral, symmetrical hyperintensities are visible on the medial portions of the thalamus (green overlay).

This finding is characteristic of Wernicke encephalopathy.

B) INCORRECT:

Degeneration of the frontotemporal lobe is seen in frontotemporal dementia, a neurodegenerative disease that is associated with mutations of genes encoding tau proteins. Frontotemporal dementia can present with confusion, ophthalmoplegia, and movement disorders, as seen in this patient. However, patients with frontotemporal dementia usually present with changes in personality and behavior early in the course of the disease, while orientation and memory are initially preserved.

C) INCORRECT:

Depigmentation of the substantia nigra is found in Parkinson disease, a neurodegenerative condition involving progressive depletion of dopaminergic neurons in the basal ganglia. Although Parkinson disease typically presents with gait abnormalities and neurocognitive dysfunction, as seen here, other classic findings, such as rigidity, akinesia, and resting tremor would be expected.

D) INCORRECT:

Widespread atrophy of the cerebral cortex is found in Alzheimer disease, a chronic neurodegenerative condition and the most common cause of dementia. Alzheimer disease typically presents with confusion and memory loss. Ophthalmoplegia, nystagmus, and ataxia in conjunction with a history of alcohol use disorder suggest a different diagnosis.
Image Description:

MRI head (T2-weighted; axial plane) of a patient with increasing memory disturbance

Bilateral cerebral atrophy with prominent Sylvian fissures (green overlay) is seen.

1: caudate nucleus; 2: putamen; 3: thalamus

E) INCORRECT:

Atrophy of the caudate and putamen is found in Huntington disease, a neurocognitive disorder caused by an increased number of CAG trinucleotide repeats in the huntingtin gene. Findings of Huntington disease include dementia, ophthalmoplegia, and movement disorder, as seen here. However, this patient lacks other typical findings of Huntington disease, such as chorea, athetosis, and dystonia.
questions.hint: Confusion, ophthalmoplegia (lateral gaze paralysis), nystagmus, and ataxia in a malnourished patient with alcohol use disorder indicate Wernicke encephalopathy.

questions.text: An otherwise healthy 45-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of episodic abdominal cramps, bloating, and flatulence. The symptoms worsen when she has pizza or ice cream and have become more frequent over the past 4 months. Lactose intolerance is suspected. Which of the following findings would most strongly support the diagnosis of lactose intolerance?

choices.text: Partial villous atrophy with eosinophilic infiltrates
Tall villi with focal collections of goblet cells
Duodenal epithelium with dense staining for chromogranin A

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Partial villous atrophy with eosinophilic infiltrates is not found in lactose intolerance but is one of the characteristic histological findings in cases of cow's milk allergy. This condition can manifest with abdominal pain and bloating, but is virtually exclusively seen in infants and also involves diarrhea. In contemporary practice, the diagnosis is most commonly made following an oral milk challenge or with identification of serum cow milk-specific IgE.

B) INCORRECT:

Periodic acid-Schiff-positive foamy macrophages are not found in lactose intolerance but occur in Whipple disease, caused by Tropheryma whipplei infection. This condition is very rare and most often manifests with chronic malabsorptive diarrhea and abdominal pain. It also causes weight loss, migratory nondeforming arthritis, lymphadenopathy, and a low-grade fever. The absence of these features suggests a different diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Crypt abscesses and colonic ulcerations are not found in lactose intolerance but are histological hallmarks of ulcerative colitis. Important gross morphological changes that are commonly observed include inflammation limited to mucosa and submucosa, easily friable mucosa, and continuous ulcers that consistently involve the rectum. While ulcerative colitis may present with episodic abdominal pain, frequent bloody diarrhea is an important part of the history. The absence of bloody diarrhea makes this diagnosis much less likely.

D) CORRECT:

Tall villi lined by simple columnar epithelium and crypts with interspaced goblet cells (crypts of Lieberkühn) and Paneth cells describes normal jejunal architecture. Patients with lactose intolerance are deficient in lactase, permitting osmotically active lactose to pass undigested to the large bowel. The molecule subsequently binds water and acts as a substrate for colonic bacteria, leading to symptoms of flatulence, bloating, and abdominal pain. Biopsy shows normal histological findings, but samples will also show decreased activity of lactase.

E) INCORRECT:

Duodenal epithelium with dense staining for chromogranin A is inconsistent with lactose intolerance but is found in a subset of patients with irritable bowel syndrome. This condition also manifests with episodic abdominal cramps, bloating, and flatulence, as in this patient. Changes in stool frequency and stool form or appearance are also common. The diagnosis is most often made using the ROME IV criteria with biopsy reserved for unusual cases.

F) INCORRECT:

Villous atrophy and crypt hyperplasia are not found in lactose intolerance but are characteristic biopsy findings in celiac disease. The underlying pathophysiology derives from intestinal hypersensitivity to gliadin. The clinical presentation is variable, ranging from solely gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., cramps, bloating, and steatorrhea, some of which are observed in this patient) to more systemic involvement (e.g., vitamin deficiencies and anemia, depression, dermatitis herpetiformis, fertility complications, and osteoporosis). This patient lacks diarrhea/steatorrhea or systemic signs typical of the disease and is significantly older than the typical age of first onset (usually teenage or young adulthood).

G) INCORRECT:

Noncaseating granulomas with lymphoid aggregates are not found in lactose intolerance but are classic histological findings of Crohn disease; gross findings can include cobblestone mucosa and discontinuous linear ulcers (“skip” ulcers), especially in the terminal ileum. This condition causes abdominal pain, diarrhea (which may be bloody), and extraintestinal symptoms involving the skin (pyoderma gangrenosum, erythema nodosum), the eyes (uveitis), and joints (arthritis), to name a few. This patient has none of these clinical features, and she is older than the typical age of onset (usually teenager or young adult).
questions.hint: Lactose intolerance does not cause bowel wall inflammation, so normal histological architecture is expected on biopsy.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of fatigue, intermittent abdominal pain, and bulky, foul-smelling diarrhea. She has had a 4-kg (8-lb 12-oz) weight loss during this period despite no changes in appetite. Examination of the abdomen shows no abnormalities. Staining of the stool with Sudan III stain shows a large number of red droplets. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ulcerative colitis (UC) can manifest with recurring episodes of diarrhea, intermittent abdominal pain, fatigue (due to anemia), and weight loss (due to recurrent inflammation and anorexia). However, patients with UC would also have symptoms such as tenesmus and mucoid or bloody stools (hematochezia), which are not reported in this patient. Fat malabsorption and steatorrhea are unusual in UC because the small intestine, which is the site of fat absorption, is usually spared.

Fat malabsorption and steatorrhea are more common with Crohn disease, which often affects the small intestine. Rarely, ileal involvement can occur in UC due to “backwash ileitis”.

B) INCORRECT:

Carcinoid syndrome can cause diarrhea, abdominal pain, and weight loss. However, carcinoid syndrome would not cause fat malabsorption and steatorrhea, and affected individuals commonly present with additional symptoms, such as cutaneous flushing, wheezing, and dyspnea, none of which are present here.

C) INCORRECT:

Symptomatic intestinal amebiasis would result in abdominal pain but fever and bloody diarrhea rather than steatorrhea would be expected, and stool examination would show trophozoites with engulfed erythrocytes or cysts with 1–4 nuclei. Moreover, the organism that causes amebiasis, E. histolytica, is most commonly found in tropical and subtropical regions, and this patient does not report any recent travel history.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a fresh stool mount (trichrome stain; very high magnification)

Three trophozoites are visible, two with phagocytosed erythrocytes that appear as dark ovoid inclusions (examples indicated by yellow overlay). The trophozoites have a single nucleus (examples indicated by blue overlay) that contains a small karyosome (examples indicated by arrowheads), surrounded by evenly distributed peripheral chromatin (examples indicated by arrows).

This appearance indicates E. histolytica, which is differentiated from the nonpathogenic E. dispar by its erythrophagocytic capacity.

D) INCORRECT:

Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) can manifest with altered bowel movements (diarrhea or constipation) and abdominal cramping but weight loss, steatorrhea, and fatigue would not occur with irritable bowel syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Lactose malabsorption can cause intermittent abdominal pain and diarrhea. However, individuals with lactose intolerance usually describe a direct connection between consumption of dairy products and onset of symptoms and complain of significant flatulence. Moreover, lactose malabsorption alone would not cause fat malabsorption and steatorrhea.

F) CORRECT:

Celiac disease (CD) is an inflammatory autoimmune condition caused by hypersensitivity to gliadin. It predominantly affects the duodenum and jejunum and is characterized by villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, and intraepithelial lymphocytosis. Patients are often asymptomatic but can present at any age with gastrointestinal symptoms such as crampy abdominal pain, fat malabsorption, and steatorrhea as well as extraintestinal manifestations (e.g., symptoms of fat-soluble vitamin deficiency, anemia, depression, dermatitis herpetiformis). Patients with celiac disease are often positive for IgA anti-tissue transglutaminase, anti-endomysial, and anti-deamidated gliadin peptide antibodies. Celiac disease is most common among individuals of northern European descent and is associated with HLA-DQ2 and HLA-DQ8 haplotypes.
questions.hint: Sudan III staining is used to identify lipids in a sample. Foul-smelling diarrhea with fat in the stool (steatorrhea) indicates fat malabsorption.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the office because of decreased appetite, nausea, vomiting, and episodic abdominal pain for the past two months. The pain is sharp, colicky, and lasts about an hour after meals. Her stools are light in appearance and difficult to flush. Physical examination shows tenderness in the right upper quadrant. Without treatment, this patient is at greatest risk for developing which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Deficiency of various water-soluble vitamins may cause glossitis. It would not be caused by malabsorption of fat-soluble vitamins (though a range of deficiencies can co-occur in some malabsorption conditions). The cholelithiasis and bile acid deficiency seen in this patient would not cause glossitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Megaloblastic anemia can be caused by vitamin B1 (thiamine), vitamin B9 (folic acid), or vitamin B12 (cobalamin) deficiencies, all of which are water-soluble vitamins. Fat malabsorption itself should not affect water-soluble vitamins, though some conditions include deficiency in both (e.g., concomitant B, D, and iron deficiency in celiac disease). Folic acid deficiency, for instance, can occur with a decreased intestinal surface area to absorb nutrients, increased physical demand (pregnancy), or decreased dietary intake. Pernicious anemia (vitamin B12 deficiency) can be due to intestinal malabsorption or lack of intrinsic factor. Thiamine deficiency is commonly observed in individuals with alcohol use disorder or diets reliant on polished rice and milled white cereals. Check for other malabsorption syndromes as a differential diagnosis.

C) CORRECT:

Low bone mineral density is observed in patients with vitamin D deficiency, which can occur secondary to fat malabsorption, decreased intake, reduced sun exposure, decreased endogenous synthesis, or end-organ resistance to vitamin D. This patient is prone to developing other fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies (vitamin A, vitamin E, vitamin K), as well.

D) INCORRECT:

Impaired wound healing is observed in vitamin C deficiency and zinc deficiency, which result from inadequate dietary intake rather than fat malabsorption. Wound healing is also delayed in megaloblastic anemia and microcytic anemia. These can occur together with vitamin D deficiency in intestinal malabsorptive conditions. However, in a patient with fat malabsorption resulting from bile acid deficiency, delayed wound healing is not expected.

E) INCORRECT:

Hepatic steatosis can be alcohol or non-alcohol related. It may be observed in patients with surplus nutritional intake, protein malnutrition, toxin-induced liver damage, or other underlying diseases. A dysbalance in fatty acid metabolism or peripheral fat absorption traps triglycerides and other fatty acids in the liver. Decreased apolipoprotein and very low-density lipoprotein (VLDL) synthesis can play a role. It is not expected in patients with fat malabsorption due to bile acid deficiency.
questions.hint: This patient's decreased appetite, nausea, vomiting, and postprandial, colicky right upper quadrant pain suggest cholelithiasis. The floating, light-colored stool likely results from fat malabsorption due to bile acid deficiency. Therefore, this patient is prone to developing fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of generalized bone pain. She has a 25-year history of Crohn disease with multiple hospitalizations for acute exacerbations, including a bowel obstruction last year. Current medications include mesalamine and bisoprolol. She is 165 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 53 kg (117 lb); her BMI is 19.5 kg/m2. Examination shows a soft abdomen and pale conjunctivae. Neurological examination shows decreased vibratory sensation over her lower extremities. Muscle strength is 4/5 in the distal groups and 3/5 in proximal groups of the lower limbs. The pelvic bones are tender to palpation. An x-ray of the pelvis shows thin cortices and multiple radiolucent bands that are perpendicular to the cortex and surrounded by a thin sclerotic margin. Which of the following laboratory findings are most likely present in this patient?



Calcium
Phosphate
Alkaline phosphatase
Parathyroid hormone



A
Normal
normal
normal
normal


B
Normal
normal
↑
normal


C
↓
↓
↑
↑


D
↑
↓
↑
↑


E
↓
↑
↑
↑


F
↑
↑
↑
↓


G
↓
↑
normal
↓
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Normal calcium, phosphorus, PTH, and ALP levels in an elderly female patient with bone pain are characteristic of osteoporosis. Osteoporosis would result in cortical thinning and increased radiolucency due to decreased bone density. However, bone sclerosis would not be expected, and the bone would be diffusely radiolucent, in contrast to the osteolytic lesions seen in this patient, which have a distinctive transverse band-like appearance on x-ray. Moreover, osteoporosis would not explain the myopathic weakness seen here.

B) INCORRECT:

High serum ALP and normal calcium, phosphorus, and PTH levels in an elderly patient with bone pain are characteristic of Paget disease of the bone (PDB). However, while PDB lesions can have a mixed lytic (radiolucent) and sclerotic appearance, they typically appear as lytic lesions within a background of diffuse sclerosis. Furthermore, a thin cortex would not be seen in PDB.
Image Description:

X-ray pelvis

Enlargement of the right hemipelvis is accompanied by coarsened trabeculation and areas of sclerosis compatible with abnormal remodeling in Paget disease (green overlay).

C) CORRECT:

Severe vitamin D deficiency can lead to hypocalcemia and hypophosphatemia by decreasing the amount of calcium and phosphate absorption in the intestine. As long as calcium levels are low, increased PTH secretion occurs in an attempt to maintain normal serum calcium levels (secondary hyperparathyroidism). PTH releases calcium stored in bone into serum by increasing bone turnover, which the elevated ALP levels (a marker of bone turnover) indicate here. Increased PTH levels also worsen hypophosphatemia by decreasing renal phosphate reabsorption.

Chronic inflammation of the ileum in patients with Crohn disease can cause impaired reabsorption of bile acids, resulting in fat malabsorption; unabsorbed fats can trap fat-soluble vitamins (e.g., vitamin D) in the intestinal lumen, causing a deficiency.

D) INCORRECT:

Decreased phosphate and increased calcium, ALP, and PTH levels are characteristic of primary hyperparathyroidism, which typically occurs in elderly women and causes bone pain. A pelvic x-ray in a patient with primary hyperparathyroidism can show cortical thinning as well as focal osteolytic lesions. However, the osteolytic lesions in patients with primary hyperparathyroidism are usually round/polygonal circumscribed lesions rather than the distinctive transverse band-like lesions seen here.

E) INCORRECT:

Bone pain with decreased calcium and increased phosphate, ALP, and PTH levels can be seen in patients with secondary hyperparathyroidism due to ESRD (renal osteodystrophy), as well as in patients with pseudohypoparathyroidism (PHP). Also, patients with PHP or renal osteodystrophy can have muscle weakness (due to myopathy) and radiological features of osteomalacia such as Looser zones, as seen here. However, renal osteodystrophy would not occur until the very late stage of CKD (i.e., when renal replacement therapy is required). PHP, on the other hand, would typically manifest during childhood with features of Albright hereditary osteodystrophy (e.g., short stature, round face, obesity, short fourth metacarpals, soft tissue calcifications, dental hypoplasia).

F) INCORRECT:

Osteolytic metastases, which appear as radiolucent lesions, can result in increased calcium, phosphorus, and ALP levels, together with decreased PTH levels. Bone metastases should be considered in any elderly patient with bone pain even if the primary tumor is not clinically evident. Hypercalcemia could also explain muscle weakness in this patient. However, the transverse band-like appearance of the radiolucent lesions in this woman suggests a different diagnosis, as osteolytic metastases usually appear as ill-defined, round lesions on x-ray.

G) INCORRECT:

Decreased calcium and PTH levels with normal serum ALP levels and increased phosphate are consistent with primary hypoparathyroidism, which can result in decreased muscle strength. However, features of bone disease are usually absent in patients with primary hypoparathyroidism. Moreover, in adults, primary hypoparathyroidism is typically caused by iatrogenic damage to the parathyroid glands during neck surgery (e.g., thyroidectomy) or neck irradiation.

Rarely (< 1% of cases), primary hypoparathyroidism occurs as a result of autoimmune disease or infiltrative diseases of the parathyroid glands (e.g., sarcoidosis, hemochromatosis, Wilson disease, metastases).
questions.hint: This patient's history of Crohn disease combined with her physical exam findings of pale conjunctiva and decreased vibratory sensation suggests malabsorption as the underlying cause for her bone pain. Bone pain combined with thin cortices and Looser zones (transverse radiolucent bands) on x-ray indicates osteomalacia.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man with a history of alcohol use disorder, chronic abdominal pain, and chronic loose stools after meals presents with progressive weight loss. During the past 4 months, he has lost at least 9.1 kg, and his BMI is now 20. He takes oxycodone for his pain, which localizes to the mid-abdomen, with radiation to the back.
He consumed up to half a liter of vodka daily for approximately 10 years but stopped drinking alcohol 2 years ago. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 20 years.
Abdominal examination is significant for moderate tenderness to deep palpation in the mid-abdomen. There is no rebound or guarding. Bowel sounds are present but few.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range



Hemoglobin (g/dL)
12
13.5–17.5


Platelet count (per mm3)
175,000
150,000–350,000


Blood urea nitrogen (mg/dL)
15
10–20


Creatinine (mg/dL)
1.3
0.8–1.3


Glucose (mg/dL)
127
70–100



Lipase (U/liter)
50
0–160


CT of the abdomen and pelvis without intravenous contrast is performed (figures 1 and 2).
Which one of the following medications is most appropriate for treating this patient for his loose stools?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Iron deficiency can be present in patients with chronic pancreatitis secondary to poor nutritional intake, but iron supplementation would not address the cause of this patient's loose stools.

B) INCORRECT:

Prednisone and azathioprine are appropriate therapies for autoimmune pancreatitis, but this condition is characterized by an enlarged, homogeneous pancreas (classically termed a “sausage pancreas”) on computed tomography.

C) INCORRECT:

Prednisone and azathioprine are appropriate therapies for autoimmune pancreatitis, but this condition is characterized by an enlarged, homogeneous pancreas (classically termed a “sausage pancreas”) on computed tomography.

D) INCORRECT:

Ursodiol is used to treat primary sclerosing cholangitis, primary biliary cholangitis, or gallstones.

E) CORRECT:

This patient’s imaging results reveal evidence of chronic pancreatitis with pancreatic atrophy, calcification, and dilation of the main pancreatic duct. Chronic pancreatitis is diagnosed based on history, examination, concomitant complications suggesting exocrine or endocrine insufficiency, and characteristic imaging findings. As in this case, patients often present with chronic epigastric abdominal pain that radiates to the back; the pain is frequently worst 15 to 30 minutes after a meal. In contrast to acute pancreatitis, amylase and lipase levels tend to be normal in chronic pancreatitis.

Pancreatic exocrine insufficiency leads to diarrhea due to malabsorption of fats (steatorrhea). Pancreatic enzyme supplementation should be initiated in patients with chronic pancreatitis who have symptoms of exocrine insufficiency, such as weight loss, steatorrhea, or fat-soluble vitamin malabsorption. Pancreatic enzymes should be co-prescribed with a proton pump inhibitor or histamine-2-receptor blocker to prevent inactivation of the drug by low gastric pH. Patients with exocrine insufficiency should be screened for deficiencies of fat-soluble vitamins (vitamins A, D, E, and K), and these should be supplemented as needed.

Key learning point: The medication most appropriate for managing exocrine pancreatic insufficiency is pancreatic enzymes.

questions.text:
A 5-year-old boy with a history of hypoplastic left heart syndrome who underwent surgical correction with a Fontan completion procedure at age 2 years is brought in by his mother. She is worried because his eyes look puffy, his socks are leaving lines on his ankles, and she is having a hard time getting his shoes tied. In addition, for the past several weeks, he has produced copious amounts of nonbloody loose stools each day.
On physical examination, his heart rate is 87 beats per minute, his respiratory rate is 23 breaths per minute, and his weight is 16.5 kg (up from 15 kg at his well-child visit 2 months ago). He is afebrile. His eyelids appear swollen, and his face looks rounder than on his last visit. His cardiovascular examination is unchanged from prior visits. His respiratory examination is notable for diminished breath sounds at the left base with dullness to percussion. No wheezes or rales are appreciated. Abdominal examination reveals distention, normoactive bowel sounds, no organomegaly, and a notable shifting fluid wave. Peripheral pitting edema is evident.
A review of recent echocardiograms shows no changes, and the surgical repair is functioning appropriately. A comprehensive metabolic panel, including electrolytes, renal function, and aminotransferases, is normal — except for the albumin level, which is 1.9 g/dL (reference range, 3.5–5.5). The total protein level is 6.8 g/dL (6.0–8.0).
Urinalysis is unremarkable, with a specific gravity of 1.020 (1.001–1.035) and no protein detected. The spot urine protein-to-creatinine ratio is <0.1 mg/mg (normal, <0.1).
Which one of the following evaluations represents the best next step for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's clinical presentation and laboratory findings, particularly given his history of a Fontan procedure, suggest protein-losing enteropathy (PLE). PLE is a rare but potentially debilitating condition that is caused by loss of serum proteins into the gastrointestinal (GI) tract. Typically, only 10% of albumin is lost through the GI tract, but in PLE, up to 60% can be lost. This loss can cause profound hypoalbuminemia, resulting in symptoms similar to those of other conditions where protein loss is prominent, such as nephrotic syndrome.

In this particular case, the patient has peripheral edema and signs of a pleural effusion and ascites. Patients with PLE may also have pericardial effusions, fat malabsorption, and deficiencies of fat-soluble vitamins. Laboratory findings in PLE typically show hypoalbuminemia, low immunoglobulins, and low ceruloplasmin.

PLE has many possible causes, including problems in the lymphatic system with resultant loss of protein-rich lymph and mucosal injury in the GI tract with increased permeability. Roughly 1% to 15% of individuals who have had a Fontan procedure for congenital heart disease develop PLE. Studies demonstrate that these individuals have underlying immune dysfunction (similar to that of PLE seen with intestinal lymphangiectasia). Other potential causes of PLE include inflammatory bowel disease, lymphoma, GI infections, celiac disease, food-induced enteropathies, small-bowel bacterial overgrowth syndrome, and primary lymphatic abnormalities, such as primary and secondary intestinal lymphangiectasia.

PLE can be diagnosed by measuring alpha1-antitrypsin in the stool. Since this protein is not typically excreted in the stool — and is resistant to proteolysis and further degradation in the intestine — it is an ideal marker to measure in stool loss. Measurement over 24 hours is much more diagnostically accurate than a spot check and is preferred when feasible. Ranges of appropriate alpha1-antitrypsin loss in the stool may vary depending on the reference laboratory being used and on whether the patient has diarrhea. Diarrhea can raise the level of protein lost in the stool independent of the presence or absence of PLE.

Key learning point: The best way to diagnose protein-losing enteropathy is a 24-hour stool alpha1-antitrypsin clearance study.

B) INCORRECT:

A paracentesis would be risky to this patient and would not provide the information needed to diagnose PLE.

C) INCORRECT:

Given that this patient has a normal urinalysis and a normal urine protein-to-creatinine ratio, underlying renal disease is less likely than PLE. Therefore, a renal biopsy is inappropriate at this time.

D) INCORRECT:

An abdominal radiograph in this patient might reveal some evidence of ascites, but it would not help identify the cause of his hypoalbuminemia and peripheral edema.

E) INCORRECT:

Given that this patient has a normal urinalysis and a normal urine protein-to-creatinine ratio, underlying renal disease is less likely than PLE. Therefore, urine protein electrophoresis is inappropriate at this time.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 2-month history of fatigue, intermittent abdominal pain, and bulky, foul-smelling diarrhea. She has had a 4-kg (8-lb 12-oz) weight loss during this period despite no changes in appetite. Staining of the stool shows a large number of lipid droplets. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ulcerative colitis (UC) can manifest with recurring episodes of diarrhea, intermittent abdominal pain, fatigue (due to anemia), and weight loss (due to recurrent inflammation and anorexia). However, patients with UC would also have symptoms such as tenesmus and mucoid or bloody stools (hematochezia), which are not reported in this patient. Fat malabsorption and steatorrhea are unusual in UC because the small intestine, which is the site of fat absorption, is usually spared.

Fat malabsorption and steatorrhea are more common with Crohn disease, which often affects the small intestine. Rarely, ileal involvement can occur in UC due to “backwash ileitis”.

B) INCORRECT:

Carcinoid syndrome can cause diarrhea, abdominal pain, and weight loss. However, carcinoid syndrome would not cause fat malabsorption and steatorrhea, and affected individuals commonly present with additional symptoms, such as cutaneous flushing, wheezing, and dyspnea, none of which are present here.

C) INCORRECT:

Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) can manifest with altered bowel movements (diarrhea or constipation) and abdominal cramping but weight loss, steatorrhea, and fatigue would not occur with irritable bowel syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Lactose malabsorption can cause intermittent abdominal pain and diarrhea. However, individuals with lactose intolerance usually describe a direct connection between consumption of dairy products and onset of symptoms and complain of significant flatulence. Moreover, lactose malabsorption alone would not cause fat malabsorption and steatorrhea.

E) CORRECT:

Celiac disease (CD) is an inflammatory autoimmune condition caused by hypersensitivity to gliadin. It predominantly affects the duodenum and jejunum and is characterized by villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, and intraepithelial lymphocytosis. Patients are often asymptomatic but can present at any age with gastrointestinal symptoms such as crampy abdominal pain, fat malabsorption, and steatorrhea as well as extraintestinal manifestations (e.g., symptoms of fat-soluble vitamin deficiency, anemia, depression, dermatitis herpetiformis). Patients with celiac disease are often positive for IgA anti-tissue transglutaminase, anti-endomysial, and anti-deamidated gliadin peptide antibodies. Celiac disease is most common among individuals of northern European descent and is associated with HLA-DQ2 and HLA-DQ8 haplotypes.
questions.hint: Foul-smelling diarrhea with fat in the stool (steatorrhea) indicates fat malabsorption.

questions.text: A previously healthy 20-year-old woman comes to the office because of recurrent abdominal cramps, bloating, and diarrhea for the past 4 months. She describes her stools as greasy, foul-smelling, and difficult to flush. During this time she has had a 6-kg (13.2-lb) weight loss. Physical examination shows pallor and cheilitis. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 11 g/dL. Analysis of a 24-hour stool sample shows 12 g (N < 7) of fat. A d-xylose test is positive and remains positive after a two-week course of rifaximin. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Bacterial overgrowth in the small intestine

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Autoimmune-mediated inflammation of the colon is the underlying mechanism of ulcerative colitis (UC), which can manifest with recurrent abdominal pain, diarrhea, anemia, and weight loss. UC most frequently occurs in individuals 15–35 years of age. However, because the small intestine is not usually affected in UC, the absorption of nutrients here remains unchanged. Therefore, steatorrhea would be absent and urine d-xylose concentration would be normal. Moreover, patients with UC typically present with bloody stools.

B) INCORRECT:

Lactose intolerance is a very common condition caused by an inability to digest lactose. While it also causes abdominal pain, bloating, and diarrhea, lactose intolerance is not associated with steatorrhea, anemia, cheilitis, or weight loss. Lactose intolerance does not affect the integrity or absorptive capacity of the small intestinal mucosa, meaning urine d-xylose levels would be normal.

C) INCORRECT:

Exocrine pancreatic insufficiency can manifest with abdominal cramps, steatorrhea, and weight loss due to lipase deficiency. However, pancreatic insufficiency does not alter the integrity or absorptive capacity of the small intestinal mucosa, meaning that urine d-xylose levels would be normal. Moreover, causes of exocrine pancreatic insufficiency like cystic fibrosis and chronic pancreatitis do not typically manifest in this age group.

D) INCORRECT:

Small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (SIBO) can manifest with diarrhea, steatorrhea, and weight loss. Bacterial proliferation impairs the absorptive capacity of the small intestine, leading to a positive d-xylose test. However, the administration of rifaximin would resolve SIBO, resulting in improved small intestinal absorptive capacity and normal urinary d-xylose levels. Additionally, this patient does not have any predisposing factors for SIBO such as blind loop syndrome, intestinal strictures (e.g., postoperative, tuberculosis, Crohn disease), or conditions that decrease intestinal motility (e.g., chronic diabetes mellitus, scleroderma).

E) CORRECT:

Hypersensitivity to gliadin is the underlying cause of celiac disease, which manifests with steatorrhea, weight loss, and features of iron deficiency (pallor and cheilitis). Malabsorption, supported by a positive d-xylose test (carbohydrate malabsorption), high fecal fat content (fat malabsorption), and low hemoglobin (micronutrient malabsorption), is typical of celiac disease. A d-xylose test that remains positive after a course of antibiotics indicates a noninfectious cause of malabsorption.

The gold standard for diagnosing celiac disease is the measurement of serum IgA anti‑tissue transglutaminase antibodies (tTG) and total IgA. If total IgA is normal and IgA tTG is high, an endoscopy-guided intestinal biopsy should be obtained (while the patient is still on a diet that contains gluten) to confirm the diagnosis.
questions.hint: D-xylose is a monosaccharide that is directly absorbed by the small intestinal mucosa without enzymatic breakdown and is primarily excreted via urine. After consumption of d-xylose, urinary levels of this monosaccharide typically increase. Loss of absorptive capacity of the small intestinal mucosa leads to a low urinary d-xylose concentration, known as a positive d-xylose test.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old man presents with a 6-month history of foul-smelling, greasy stools and a 4.5 kg weight loss. He experiences chronic epigastric pain radiating to his back and has consumed three to four alcoholic beverages daily for the past 10 years. He denies any use of nutritional supplements and has reduced dietary fat intake with no marked improvement in stool characteristics. Physical examination reveals mild epigastric tenderness without organomegaly. Laboratory studies show normal serum amylase and lipase (see report).
Abdominal imaging: Multiple calcifications in the pancreas
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to address his malabsorption?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Total parenteral nutrition is reserved for severe malabsorption or non-functional digestive systems. This patient's malabsorption is due to pancreatic enzyme deficiency, which can be managed with enzyme supplementation. His gastrointestinal tract is functional, and TPN carries risks like infections and metabolic complications.

B) CORRECT:

Chronic pancreatitis leads to progressive destruction of pancreatic tissue, resulting in exocrine insufficiency and malabsorption. This manifests as steatorrhea due to a deficiency in digestive enzymes, particularly lipase. Oral pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy provides these enzymes, improving fat digestion and nutrient absorption. Imaging findings of pancreatic calcifications confirm the diagnosis, indicating long-term pancreatic damage. Enzyme supplementation during meals directly addresses the deficiency, alleviating malabsorption symptoms and improving nutritional status.

Key learning point: In patients with chronic pancreatitis and exocrine pancreatic insufficiency, pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy, particularly lipase supplementation, is the most effective strategy to control symptoms such as steatorrhea.

C) INCORRECT:

Proton pump inhibitors are used for acid-related disorders like gastroesophageal reflux disease, not for enzyme deficiency in chronic pancreatitis. The patient's malabsorption results from pancreatic exocrine insufficiency, not acid hypersecretion. Enzyme replacement, not acid suppression, is necessary to address the underlying cause of malabsorption.

D) INCORRECT:

While chronic pancreatitis can lead to fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies, high-dose supplementation does not address the enzyme deficiency causing malabsorption. Without adequate pancreatic enzymes, absorption of these vitamins remains impaired. The focus should be on enzyme replacement to restore normal digestion.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 2-month history of decreased appetite, nausea, vomiting, and episodic abdominal pain. The pain is sharp, colicky, and occurs for about an hour after meals. She reports that her stools are light in color and difficult to flush. On examination, there is tenderness in the right upper quadrant. Without treatment, this patient is at greatest risk for developing which one of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Impaired wound healing is observed in vitamin C deficiency and zinc deficiency, which result from inadequate dietary intake rather than fat malabsorption. Wound healing is also delayed in megaloblastic anemia and microcytic anemia. These can occur together with vitamin D deficiency in intestinal malabsorptive conditions. However, in a patient with fat malabsorption resulting from bile acid deficiency, delayed wound healing is not expected.

B) INCORRECT:

Deficiency of various water-soluble vitamins may cause glossitis. It would not be caused by malabsorption of fat-soluble vitamins (though a range of deficiencies can co-occur in some malabsorption conditions). The cholelithiasis and bile acid deficiency seen in this patient would not cause glossitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Megaloblastic anemia can be caused by vitamin B1 (thiamine), vitamin B9 (folic acid), or vitamin B12 (cobalamin) deficiencies, all of which are water-soluble vitamins. Fat malabsorption itself should not affect water-soluble vitamins, though some conditions include deficiency in both (e.g., concomitant B, D, and iron deficiency in celiac disease). Folic acid deficiency, for instance, can occur with a decreased intestinal surface area to absorb nutrients, increased physical demand (pregnancy), or decreased dietary intake. Pernicious anemia (vitamin B12 deficiency) can be due to intestinal malabsorption or lack of intrinsic factor. Thiamine deficiency is commonly observed in individuals with alcohol use disorder or diets reliant on polished rice and milled white cereals. Check for other malabsorption syndromes as a differential diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Hepatic steatosis can be alcohol or non-alcohol related. It may be observed in patients with surplus nutritional intake, protein malnutrition, toxin-induced liver damage, or other underlying diseases. A dysbalance in fatty acid metabolism or peripheral fat absorption traps triglycerides and other fatty acids in the liver. Decreased apolipoprotein and very low-density lipoprotein (VLDL) synthesis can play a role. It is not expected in patients with fat malabsorption due to bile acid deficiency.

E) CORRECT:

Low bone mineral density is observed in patients with vitamin D deficiency, which can occur secondary to fat malabsorption, decreased intake, reduced sun exposure, decreased endogenous synthesis, or end-organ resistance to vitamin D. This patient is prone to developing other fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies (vitamin A, vitamin E, vitamin K), as well.

Key learning point: Fat malabsorption from cholelithiasis can cause deficiencies in fat-soluble vitamins, especially vitamin D, increasing the risk of low bone mineral density and osteomalacia.
questions.hint: This patient's decreased appetite, nausea, vomiting, and postprandial, colicky right upper quadrant pain suggest cholelithiasis. The floating, light-colored stool likely results from fat malabsorption due to bile acid deficiency. Therefore, this patient is prone to developing fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 2-month history of fatigue, intermittent abdominal pain, and bulky, foul-smelling diarrhea. She has lost 4 kg during this period despite no change in appetite. Stool staining reveals a large number of lipid droplets. Which one of the following is the most likely underlying cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lactose malabsorption can cause intermittent abdominal pain and diarrhea. However, individuals with lactose intolerance usually describe a direct connection between consumption of dairy products and onset of symptoms and complain of significant flatulence. Moreover, lactose malabsorption alone would not cause fat malabsorption and steatorrhea.

B) INCORRECT:

Carcinoid syndrome can cause diarrhea, abdominal pain, and weight loss. However, carcinoid syndrome would not cause fat malabsorption and steatorrhea, and affected individuals commonly present with additional symptoms, such as cutaneous flushing, wheezing, and dyspnea, none of which are present here.

C) INCORRECT:

Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) can manifest with altered bowel movements (diarrhea or constipation) and abdominal cramping but weight loss, steatorrhea, and fatigue would not occur with irritable bowel syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Ulcerative colitis (UC) can manifest with recurring episodes of diarrhea, intermittent abdominal pain, fatigue (due to anemia), and weight loss (due to recurrent inflammation and anorexia). However, patients with UC would also have symptoms such as tenesmus and mucoid or bloody stools (hematochezia), which are not reported in this patient. Fat malabsorption and steatorrhea are unusual in UC because the small intestine, which is the site of fat absorption, is usually spared.

Fat malabsorption and steatorrhea are more common with Crohn disease, which often affects the small intestine. Rarely, ileal involvement can occur in UC due to “backwash ileitis”.

E) CORRECT:

Celiac disease (CD) is an inflammatory autoimmune condition caused by hypersensitivity to gliadin. It predominantly affects the duodenum and jejunum and is characterized by villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, and intraepithelial lymphocytosis. Patients are often asymptomatic but can present at any age with gastrointestinal symptoms such as crampy abdominal pain, fat malabsorption, and steatorrhea as well as extraintestinal manifestations (e.g., symptoms of fat-soluble vitamin deficiency, anemia, depression, dermatitis herpetiformis). Patients with celiac disease are often positive for IgA anti-tissue transglutaminase, anti-endomysial, and anti-deamidated gliadin peptide antibodies. Celiac disease is most common among individuals of northern European descent and is associated with HLA-DQ2 and HLA-DQ8 haplotypes.

Key learning point: Celiac disease is a common cause of steatorrhea due to autoimmune-mediated small intestinal villous atrophy leading to fat malabsorption.
questions.hint: Foul-smelling diarrhea with fat in the stool (steatorrhea) indicates fat malabsorption.

questions.text: A previously healthy 20-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 4-month history of recurrent abdominal cramps, bloating, and diarrhea. She describes her stools as greasy, foul-smelling, and difficult to flush. She has lost 6 kg during this period. On examination, she has pallor and cheilitis. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 110 g/L (115–155). Analysis of a 24-hour stool sample reveals 12 g (N < 5) of fat. A d-xylose test is positive and remains positive after a two-week course of rifaximin. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of her condition?

choices.text: Bacterial overgrowth in the small intestine.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (SIBO) can manifest with diarrhea, steatorrhea, and weight loss. Bacterial proliferation impairs the absorptive capacity of the small intestine, leading to a positive d-xylose test. However, the administration of rifaximin would resolve SIBO, resulting in improved small intestinal absorptive capacity and normal urinary d-xylose levels. Additionally, this patient does not have any predisposing factors for SIBO such as blind loop syndrome, intestinal strictures (e.g., postoperative, tuberculosis, Crohn disease), or conditions that decrease intestinal motility (e.g., chronic diabetes mellitus, scleroderma).

B) INCORRECT:

Exocrine pancreatic insufficiency can manifest with abdominal cramps, steatorrhea, and weight loss due to lipase deficiency. However, pancreatic insufficiency does not alter the integrity or absorptive capacity of the small intestinal mucosa, meaning that urine d-xylose levels would be normal. Moreover, causes of exocrine pancreatic insufficiency like cystic fibrosis and chronic pancreatitis do not typically manifest in this age group.

C) INCORRECT:

Lactose intolerance is a very common condition caused by an inability to digest lactose. While it also causes abdominal pain, bloating, and diarrhea, lactose intolerance is not associated with steatorrhea, anemia, cheilitis, or weight loss. Lactose intolerance does not affect the integrity or absorptive capacity of the small intestinal mucosa, meaning urine d-xylose levels would be normal.

D) CORRECT:

Hypersensitivity to gliadin is the underlying cause of celiac disease, which manifests with steatorrhea, weight loss, and features of iron deficiency (pallor and cheilitis). Malabsorption, supported by a positive d-xylose test (carbohydrate malabsorption), high fecal fat content (fat malabsorption), and low hemoglobin (micronutrient malabsorption), is typical of celiac disease. A d-xylose test that remains positive after a course of antibiotics indicates a noninfectious cause of malabsorption.

The gold standard for diagnosing celiac disease is the measurement of serum IgA anti‑tissue transglutaminase antibodies (tTG) and total IgA. If total IgA is normal and IgA tTG is high, an endoscopy-guided intestinal biopsy should be obtained (while the patient is still on a diet that contains gluten) to confirm the diagnosis.

Key learning point: Celiac disease is caused by hypersensitivity to gliadin, leading to immune-mediated small intestinal mucosal damage and resulting in malabsorption of nutrients, including fats and micronutrients.

E) INCORRECT:

Autoimmune-mediated inflammation of the colon is the underlying mechanism of ulcerative colitis (UC), which can manifest with recurrent abdominal pain, diarrhea, anemia, and weight loss. UC most frequently occurs in individuals 15–35 years of age. However, because the small intestine is not usually affected in UC, the absorption of nutrients here remains unchanged. Therefore, steatorrhea would be absent and urine d-xylose concentration would be normal. Moreover, patients with UC typically present with bloody stools.
questions.hint: D-xylose is a monosaccharide that is directly absorbed by the small intestinal mucosa without enzymatic breakdown and is primarily excreted via urine. After consumption of d-xylose, urinary levels of this monosaccharide typically increase. Loss of absorptive capacity of the small intestinal mucosa leads to a low urinary d-xylose concentration, known as a positive d-xylose test.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents to the ED with worsening fatigue, peripheral edema, and chronic diarrhea over the past 4 months. She reports a 12-pound unintentional weight loss and poor appetite. Vital signs are stable. Examination reveals pallor and bilateral pitting edema. Labs show hemoglobin 9.2 g/dL, MCV 102 fL, albumin 2.8 g/dL, potassium 3.1 mEq/L, calcium 8.4 mg/dL, and prolonged PT. What is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Hydrogen breath test for lactose intolerance
Tissue transglutaminase IgA and anti-endomysial antibodies
Vitamin B12, folate, and fat-soluble vitamin levels
Stool culture and ova and parasites examination

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hydrogen breath testing evaluates lactose intolerance, which causes isolated carbohydrate malabsorption. However, this patient has multiple nutritional deficiencies. Testing for a single food intolerance would delay broader diagnostic workup and treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

These tests are useful for diagnosing celiac disease but are not the first step in ED management of a patient with suspected malabsorption and multiple vitamin deficiencies. Initial lab evaluation should focus on confirming specific deficiencies to guide immediate care and disposition planning. Celiac testing can be pursued as part of follow-up workup.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient presents with signs and symptoms of malabsorption, including weight loss, diarrhea, macrocytic anemia, hypoalbuminemia, and fat-soluble vitamin–related abnormalities (e.g., prolonged PT from vitamin K deficiency). Further workup for underlying etiology should occur outpatient or inpatient depending on severity.

D) INCORRECT:

These tests evaluate pancreatic exocrine insufficiency, a potential cause of malabsorption. However, they are not typically ordered from the ED due to limited immediate management impact. The priority is confirming and managing the identified nutritional deficiencies before pursuing cause-specific outpatient testing.

E) INCORRECT:

Infectious causes should be considered in acute or travel-related diarrhea, but the chronic nature of this patient’s symptoms, coupled with multiple lab abnormalities (macrocytic anemia, hypoalbuminemia, electrolyte derangements), points toward malabsorption.

questions.text:
A 2-month-old girl is brought to the pediatrician for a follow-up visit 2 weeks after undergoing a hepatoportoenterostomy for biliary atresia. Before surgery, she had persistent jaundice, pale stools, and poor weight gain. Her prenatal and birth history were unremarkable. She is breastfed exclusively. Her parents have no known medical conditions. She takes no medications. She appears alert and active. Her weight is at the 10th percentile. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows scleral icterus and mild hepatomegaly. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Results of laboratory studies are shown:


Prothrombin time
12 seconds


Serum



 Albumin
3.7 g/dL


 Bilirubin



 Total

3.5 mg/dL


 Direct

2.8 mg/dL


 Aspartate aminotransferase
52 U/L


 Alanine aminotransferase
61 U/L


Her parents ask about additional steps to ensure optimal growth and development after surgery. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation for this patient?

choices.text: Restriction of dietary protein to prevent hepatic encephalopathy
Supplementation with vitamins A, D, E, and K
Increasing feeding frequency to promote weight gain

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Protein restriction is only indicated in infants with biliary atresia who have evidence of severe hepatic dysfunction or overt hepatic encephalopathy, which is rare in individuals without advanced cirrhosis. Protein is crucial for growth and development in infants, and unnecessary restriction may worsen nutritional status and impair growth.

B) CORRECT:

Infants with biliary atresia, even after a hepatoportoenterostomy (Kasai procedure), remain at risk for cholestasis and impaired bile flow, as evidenced by persistent direct hyperbilirubinemia. Impaired bile flow causes fat malabsorption and impairs absorption of fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, and K), resulting in deficiencies. Supplementation with all four fat-soluble vitamins is essential to prevent deficiencies and to support normal growth and development.

C) INCORRECT:

Ursodeoxycholic acid is sometimes used to promote bile flow in pediatric liver conditions. However, this medication alone does not address all the nutritional and developmental needs of infants with persistent cholestasis. Another recommendation is more appropriate to support optimal growth and prevent complications in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Increasing feeding frequency or caloric density can help address poor weight gain in infants with chronic illnesses such as biliary atresia. However, in a patient with persistent cholestasis, simply increasing caloric intake does not address the underlying defect in bile-mediated absorption of certain essential nutrients.

E) INCORRECT:

While beneficial, breastmilk alone is insufficient for infants with persistent cholestasis because it causes poor absorption of other essential nutrients. Infants with ongoing cholestasis require more than just breastmilk to meet all of their nutritional needs, even if they are feeding well and gaining weight. While regular monitoring is appropriate, dietary modification is also necessary for this patient.
questions.hint: Persistent cholestasis after hepatoportoenterostomy impairs micelle formation due to decreased bile salt levels, leading to fat malabsorption.
